Infectious Diseases (e.g., Viral Hemorrhagic Fevers, Dengue Fever)
Leukemia (in specific forms affecting the skin)
Phrynoderma (Follicular hyperkeratosis due to vitamin A deficiency)

Infectious Diseases (e.g., Viral or Bacterial Infections)

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in certain blood-forming cells of the bone marrow. It can lead to easy bleeding, basophilia, and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Acute Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A rapidly progressing cancer of the blood and bone marrow. Symptoms can include easy bleeding and cognitive dysfunction due to the infiltration of leukemic cells into different body parts.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: A virus that attacks the immune system. Advanced stages can lead to cognitive dysfunction and an increased risk of infections that might cause symptoms like leukoplakia and easy bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that can cause mouth sores (similar to leukoplakia), skin problems, and other symptoms like easy bleeding due to vascular involvement.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including the brain (leading to cognitive dysfunction) and blood cells (causing easy bleeding and basophilia in some cases).

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Deficiency of vitamin B12 can lead to cognitive dysfunction and may have hematological effects such as easy bleeding. It can also cause leukoplakia due to effects on mucous membranes.

diagnoses.name: Liver Cirrhosis
diagnoses.description: A late stage of scarring (fibrosis) of the liver caused by many forms of liver diseases and conditions. Symptoms can include cognitive dysfunction (due to hepatic encephalopathy) and easy bleeding (due to coagulopathy).

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over time. It can lead to cognitive dysfunction and disturbances in platelet function, causing easy bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Wegener's Granulomatosis (GPA)
diagnoses.description: A type of vasculitis that can cause nosebleeds or post-nasal drip and might lead to kidney failure, which in turn can cause cognitive dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
diagnoses.description: A bleeding disorder in which the immune system destroys platelets, which are necessary for normal blood clotting. Patients experience easy bleeding and might have other autoimmune symptoms including cognitive issues.

diagnoses: Acid Reflux Disease / Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Asthma (with normal pulmonary function tests during symptom-free periods)
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's granulomatosis)

diagnoses.name: Mast cell activation syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which mast cells mistakenly release too many chemical mediators, leading to a variety of symptoms including dermatographism, possibly contributing to tinnitus, and can indirectly cause systemic symptoms that might influence hyperglycemia and leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder characterized by hyperglycemia. Poor glucose control can lead to infections (causing leukocytosis), nausea or vomiting, and may indirectly affect hearing leading to tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Chronic kidney disease (CKD)
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function. CKD can cause hyperglycemia, elevated white blood cell count as a response to the body stress or infections, and uremia, which can result in nausea/vomiting and tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Urticaria (hives)
diagnoses.description: An outbreak of swollen, pale red bumps, plaques, or welts on the skin that appear suddenly as a result of allergies or for other reasons. Dermatographism is a form of chronic urticaria. It can be associated with systemic reactions.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune disorders
diagnoses.description: Diseases caused by an immune response against the body's own cells and tissues. Some autoimmune disorders can cause hyperglycemia (Type 1 diabetes), leukocytosis as a response to inflammation, dermatographism due to skin involvement, and vomiting due to gastrointestinal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Infections
diagnoses.description: Various infections can cause leukocytosis, hyperglycemia (especially in people with diabetes), vomiting, and tinnitus (especially if the infection involves the ear). Dermatographism could be related to allergic reactions or skin involvement secondary to the infection.

diagnoses.name: Drug reactions
diagnoses.description: Certain medications can cause allergic reactions including dermatographism, raise blood glucose levels, increase white blood cell count, induce vomiting, and even cause tinnitus either directly or through ototoxic effects.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid disorders
diagnoses.description: Hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism can indirectly cause hyperglycemia, contribute to an increased white blood cell count, and cause systemic symptoms that might lead to vomiting. Dermatographism and tinnitus are less commonly associated but can be present due to the body's overall imbalance.

diagnoses.name: Stress or Anxiety
diagnoses.description: Psychological stress can exacerbate or trigger dermatographism and tinnitus. It can also affect blood glucose levels and immune system functioning, potentially influencing leukocytosis and causing gastrointestinal symptoms like vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Food Allergy/Intolerance
diagnoses.description: Reactions to certain foods can trigger a wide range of symptoms including dermatographism, vomiting, and indirectly cause hyperglycemia. Leukocytosis can occur as part of the allergic response.
A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue, muscle pain, and lymphadenitis, along with other symptoms. However, it typically does not explain delayed puberty or blepharospasm directly.
An autoimmune disorder that can cause lymphadenitis, muscle pain, and oral pain. It might also indirectly affect growth and development, potentially contributing to delayed puberty.
An autoimmune disease that primarily causes dry eyes and dry mouth (leading to oral pain), but can also lead to lymphadenitis and muscle pain. Delayed puberty is not a common symptom.
Can cause lymphadenitis, muscle pain, and oral pain due to opportunistic infections. Delayed puberty can occur in children due to the chronic illness and its impact on growth.
An inflammatory disease that can cause lymphadenitis, muscle pain, and eye symptoms. Though rare, it can affect hormones and potentially impact puberty.
Caused by the Borrelia bacteria, it can lead to muscle pain, lymphadenitis, and oral pain. If chronic, it might also indirectly affect growth and developmental milestones like puberty.
A mycobacterial infection that can cause lymphadenitis and muscle pain. Severe cases or those with significant disease burden may also experience delayed growth or puberty.
An autoimmune disease that can present with lymphadenitis, muscle pain, and oral ulcers, potentially affecting multiple body systems, including hormonal regulation.

A focal dystonia characterized by involuntary blinking or eyelid twitching. While primarily affecting the eyelids, it does not account for the other symptoms but could be part of a broader neurological condition impacting other areas.
A rare, self-limiting condition that causes lymphadenitis and can have systemic symptoms including muscle pain. It is less likely to be associated with oral pain or delayed puberty directly.

diagnoses: Myeloproliferative Neoplasms (MPNs) including other forms beyond Polycythemia Vera
Peanut or Other Severe Food Allergy
Anaphylaxis (in severe cases with systemic reaction)
Anisakiasis (from ingestion of raw or undercooked fish)

diagnoses.description: A type of headache accompanied by visual, sensory, or speech disturbances (aura) including scotoma (blind spots) and scintillation (flashes of light), often followed by numbness and aphasia.
Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA produces similar symptoms to a stroke, including numbness, aphasia, and visual disturbances, but usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage.
A condition where the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, causing symptoms like numbness on one side of the body, difficulty speaking (aphasia), and visual problems.
A disease of the central nervous system that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including visual disturbances, sensory issues like numbness, and difficulty with coordination and speech.
Disorders that can present with a wide range of neurological symptoms including sensory disturbances like numbness and visual phenomena, and sometimes aphasia after the seizure.
Tumors in the brain can press on nerve tissues and blood vessels, leading to symptoms such as numbness, speech difficulties, and visual disruptions depending on the tumor's location.
A rare type of stroke that occurs during a migraine with aura, exhibiting symptoms like weakness, aphasia, visual disturbances but specifically linked to a migraine event.
A migraine that produces severe and unusual symptoms, such as prolonged aura, numbness, and speech disturbances, which can mimic a stroke.
A rare form of stroke caused by a blood clot in the brain's venous sinuses. It can cause headache, visual disturbances, aphasia, and numbness.

A condition where patients present with neurological symptoms such as numbness, paralysis, or sensory disturbances like blindness or visual impairments, including scotoma and scintillation, that cannot be explained by medical evaluation. Psychological factors are believed to play a role in the development of these symptoms.

diagnoses: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Oral Cavity
Schizophrenia (or other psychiatric conditions causing secondary systemic issues)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Infectious Diseases (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C) with Immune Complex Formation
Chronic Kidney Disease secondary to glomerulonephritis
